story: The important thing to keep in mind, apparently, is a sleep cycle.Rather than simply getting more sleep when you’re tired, you need to get in tune with your sleep cycle – andyou wake up in the middle of a sleep cycle rather than at the end you might actually feel more tired evenyou slept for longer, so the latest findings from blinds indicates.A sleep cycle last approximately  minutes and during that you are meant to move through five stages of sleep.Four of those stages are non-rapid eye movementand one stage of rapid eye movement .The first stage is a light sleep and then you fall into a deeper and deeper sleep as you move through the stages.As stage four is a deep sleepyou wake up at this stage in the cycle then its more than likely you’ll feel groggy.The fth stage is REM and is when you supposedly dream.So using that as a basis,you need to wake up at am to start the working day then you need to go to bed at either .pm or .pm.If neither of those appeal then .am or .am would also be best.These precise times take into account the average of  minutes it takes people to fall asleep naturally.Similarly,you need to wake up at am the optimal times to go to bed are .pm, .pm, .pm or even .am.If you have to wake up at am then bedtime should be at .pm, .am, .am or even .am.The Sleep Calculator website says: Getting a good nights sleep is about more than simply going to bed early – its about waking up at the right time too.Using a formula based on the bodys natural rhythms, the Sleep Calculator will work out the best time for you to rise or go to sleep.

title: passport queues set to get longer as more visitors are allowed to use them
story: The Chancellor said in his Budget today that he would open up e-passport gates at Heathrow and other airports to include people from the US, Canada, New Zealand, Japan and Australia.Philip Hammond said today: Today I can announce a package of measures to stimulate business investment and send a message loud and clear to the rest of the world: Britain is open for business.The move is part of plans to show that Britain is open for business after we leave the EU.But currently the e-passport gates at Britains airports are only available to people in the European Economic Area.Adding five more countries to that list means Brits are likely to have to queue for longer in future.But the Budgets small prints said it would signicantly improve the flow of passengers overall.Tim Alderslade, chief executive of Airlines UK - the industry association that represents UK carriers, said: As passenger numbers continue to rise, UK Border Force must be adequately resourced and adopt new approaches in order to prevent a repeat of last summer, where y border queues were experienced at a number of UK airports.This announcement is a welcome step in the right direction, enabling millions more travellers to be processed more quickly.Its important now to ensure Government rapidly implements the required technical changes so passengers can take advantage as quickly as possible.The e-gates first were introduced in the UK in , and now  are in place at  air and rail ports across the UK.They require fewer staff to operate as the checks are done digitally using scanners.Facial recognition technology is used to compare the passengers face to the photo in their passport.Ministers said they help speed up arrivals, and more are to be put in place in future.He went on to reveal a new tax relief for non-residential buildings, an increase in how much people can invest in the country, and a £billion fund for lending.Start-up loan funding was also set to be extended, as well as the New Enterprise Allowance.Highlights of todays Budget include:

title: suzy lamplugh cops search for remains
story: The property in Sutton Coldfield, West Midlands, is the former home of the mother of prime suspect John Cannan. Suzy, , was abducted in  and declared dead, presumed murdered, in .It follows information that Cannan may have buried -year-old Suzy there after abducting and murdering her. The home was first searched in  but cops have now ed to dig up a section of the garden.Excavation work was focusing on an old corrugated iron garage in the back garden of the semi- detached property in Sutton Coldfield, West Mids.A forensic tent was also placed over an area of concrete patio.Suzy disappeared after going to meet a client named “Mr Kipper” to show him two houses in Fulham, South West London in July .Her body has never been found, though she was declared dead — presumed murdered — in .It remains one of Britain’s most infamous unsolved murders.But cold case review detectives now suspect that after murdering Suzy, Cannan may have driven to what was then his mother’s home.They fear he put Suzy’s body in an inspection pit in the garage he used for working on cars, before filling it with concrete.The corrugated iron structure was yesterday dismantled by Met Police specialist search cops to enable excavation work to start.Ground-penetrating radar was used to scan the area and a tent was erected where the garage stood.The team of about a dozen officers had shovels and garden forks on hand for digging.A side entrance to the garden via a small private track, was cordoned off at around am as the search team arrived in eight police vans.Officers conducted the grim search just a few feet from a children’s trampoline and a swing.The importance of the search is enhanced by Cannan’s habit of ing to his mother’s home after committing serious crimes.It is believed that his mother Sheila is in her s and living in a dferent part of the country.There is no suggestion that she was involved in or had any knowledge of this or any of his crimes.She previously spoke about the case in , saying: He has never discussed this with me, and I have never asked him.I suppose I have had it on my mind for so long. I am getting old, and you feel guilty yourself. Hes mine, I cant deny that. He s my son who I brought up.But I still cant understand anything about why. Thats what disturbs you. Its very upsetting really.The search at her former home is expected to go on for several days. A forensic archaeologist is guiding cops during the search.It is being carried out with the full consent of a family who have lived there since Cannan’s mother moved out in .The cold case review team is not conducting a full-scale investigation into Suzy’s abduction and murder but are said to be acting on specic information relating to the potential burial site.A source said: “The couple who lived there were shocked when the police came to them asking to search their garden.“But they have given their full consent to the search.“Police have already conducted a cursory examination there and established that everything fits with what they were told.”Insurance marketer Phillip Carey said he purchased the home in Sutton Coldfield, from Sheila Cannan in .The -year-old said: From our point of view, we bought the house  years ago, from the suspected persons mother, Sheila.We knew who she was, we became aware who she was as we went through the relationship, and obviously it was high profile at the time.It is not the first time police have searched at the family home, Mr Carey said, with officers looking in a similar area about  years ago before ing on Monday.This time it is very much about ultimately eliminating the property from the process entirely - it is just a matter of an ending, for us, he added.Police have since defended the decision not to dig up the garden more than a decade ago after searching the home in .DCI Jim Dickie, who led the investigation over six years from , told the BBC: They must have had new information or intelligence. We did not dig or carry out a search of the garden because there was no evidence to suggest the body was secreted there.John Cannan was in Fulham on the day of the murder. He murdered Shirley Banks and raped and abducted other women.He was Mr Kipper - he remains the prime suspect for Suzy Lamplughs murder.Cannan, now , is serving a minimum  years in Full Sutton prison for the murder of Shirley Banks in .Information was first received in December  from one of Cannan’s fellow prisoners, that Suzy was buried under the patio at his mother’s house.The inmate came forward after police took the highly unusual step of naming Cannan as their prime suspect when the CPS ruled there was insufficient information to charge him with Suzy’s murder.Cannan is serving three le sentences for murdering newlywed Shirley in Bristol in October , attempting to kidnap a woman the previous evening and raping another woman at knepoint in Reading, Berks, a year earlier.The suspected serial killer was captured three weeks after Shirley, , vanished, when he robbed a dress shop assistant at knepoint in Leamington Spa, Warwicks.A road tax disc from Shirley’s car was found in the glove box of Cannan’s black BMW. It led to the discovery of her Mini Clubman in his garage at a block of flats where he lived in Clton, Bristol.The Mini had the  number plate SLP S — suspected of being a reference to Suzy’s name.Cannan was given a whole le sentence at Exeter crown court in April , but it was commuted on appeal to a -year minimum tarf, meaning he is eligible to apply for parole in four years.Ex-car salesman Cannan is also a leading suspect in the murder of Bournemouth insurance worker Sandra Court, , whose body was found in a water-filled ditch after she was abducted in May .Despite a wealth of circumstantial evidence in Suzy’s murder pointing towards Cannan, the case against him has been undermined by a lack of forensic evidence and a body.Three major searches for Suzy were conducted in the early s and in .The first two focused on a former barracks site in Worcestershire.Then in  a field near the barracks was searched, along with a Quantock Hills earthwork site in Somerset known as Dead Woman’s Ditch, where Shirley’s body was found in .The Met Police said last night: “The search follows information received in relation to a historical unsolved investigation.“We will not be commenting on speculation surrounding the search, or providing any further information at this time.”THE search at the former home of John Cannan’s mother comes too late for Suzy’s parents.Her solicitor father Paul died in June this year aged  after a long battle with Parkinson’s disease. Her mother Diana, , died in .Following their daughter’s disappearance, the Lamplughs, of East Sheen, South West London, set up the Suzy Lamplugh Trust to promote safety of women in memory of their daughter.They campaigned for better taxi safety and laws protecting victims of stalking.The trust today said the development was a reminder over the continuing tragedy of Suzys death.They said in a statement: The thoughts of everyone at Suzy Lamplugh Trust are with Suzys family todayToday we continue the work ofPaul and Diana to reduce violence and aggression in society, supporting workplaces to help their lone and frontline workers be safer and feel safer.Todays news reminds us once again of the continuing tragedy of Suzys story and the importance of employers taking responsibility for the personal safety of their staff.The couple, who have three other children, Richard, Tamsin and Lizzie who were both awarded the OBE in .They were convinced of Cannan’s guilt.Mr Lamplugh spoke out after the  decision by the CPS not to prosecute.He said: “Suzy was a lovely girl and we and her brother and sisters and her many friends still miss her enormously.“It’s greatly distressing that Suzy’s body has not been found nor do we know how she was killed.“The least the offender can do now is tell us where the body is.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: glenn hoddle family overwhelmed by support
story: Hoddle had been appearing live on Robbie Savages show Saturday Morning Sav when he collapsed and cracked his head.His family said in a statement: Glenn and his family are overwhelmed by the best wishes sent from Tottenham Hotspur staff, players, ex-players and most importantly all our tremendous supporters since he was taken ill on Saturday.It has been a huge comfort to have your support and memories to lt us all at such a dficult time, so thank you. Lets hope for a win tonight to make Hod smile. COYS.Glenn Hoddle is showing signs he will make a full recovery after having major heart surgery.The former England manager,  is said to be up and speaking with friends and family just days after collapsing on set on BT Sport after suffering a massive heart attack.It’s thought the pundit is now out of intensive care and will suffer no long term health effects thanks to the quick efforts of BT sound engineer Simon Daniels.A pal of the former Spurs and Cha ace said: All the indications are that he is responding well to the treatment and could make a full recovery in the course of time.He had a good nights sleep and was talking on Sunday. Hes had major heart surgery.“Hes going to take some time to recover but there are no signs of brain damage and there are signs he is going to make a full recovery.Simon Daniels, a freelance sound engineer with BT, used a defibrillator to keep Hoddle alive after he suffered a heart attack at the studios on Saturday. Simon,  who is also a special constable, told The Sun yesterday: “It was nothing.”Glenn was taken ill shortly before he was due to appear as a pundit on the BT Sport Score show on Saturday.A statement on behalf of the family on Sunday said Hoddle remained in a serious condition but continues to respond well to treatment.The spokesman refused to comment that he was now out of intensive care.The football world has sent a flood of support to the former Spurs midfielder, who won  caps for England. England manager Gareth Southgate, who played under Hoddle for England, said: Everybody across the game is right behind one of English footballs greats and we are willing him to pull through.Greg Clarke, the FA chairman, added: All of us at Wembley and St Georges Park are thinking of Glenn and hoping for positive news. Our thoughts are also with his family and friends at what will be an extremely dficult time.Crystal Palace manager Roy Hodgson, a friend of Hoddle, said after his sides draw with Arsenal: I think its something which puts the game of football into perspective.

title: fedex delivery worker louisiana finds baby crawling truck
story: The unsupervised child was spotted by FedEx employee Byron Nash as he pulled up to the property in Lake Charles, Louisiana, on Friday.He posted video of the shocking encounter to Facebook, saying: “This baby was crawling outside under my truck after my truck was parked to make a delivery, luckily I seen her before I backed out. No supervision in sight.”The child is seen clearly in the footage, dwarfed by the huge wheels of Byron’s truck, as she stares up at him innocently.While filming the close-call, the astonished driver is heard saying: “This baby is right under my truck and her parents arent nowhere to be found! Look at this, this baby is outside by herself.”The caring driver then swoops down to pick up the child, as well as the package, and heads towards the family home to confront the parents.He is met by a woman who is supposed to have been minding the child, and is gobsmacked to learn she had no idea the child had crawled outside.Byron is seen approaching the entrance of the property through the garage, where he finds an open door.He shouts through: “Hello! Hey! This baby was under my truck!”.The emerging woman responds: “Oh s***! Oh God!”Byron explains to her that he saw the child crawling under his tyre, having first seen a dog walking near his vehicle.Once the dog was out of his eye line, Byron’s eyes fell on the child crawling under his vehicle.Speaking to the woman, he is heard saying that the encounter “scared him at first”, to which she replies: “It would have scared the f*** out of me too, I would have been tripping.”He responds: “Thank God I was paying attention becauseI had of backed up she would have been out of here.”Before leaving, he advises the woman to keep her doors closed in the future.She responds by saying the house belongs to her mother, who has “everything open, all the doors, all the windows.”He then advises her to use a playpen, which the woman claims to have but did not use at the time.Speaking to the MailOnline, the dad-of-one said: “I thought how could somebody leave their child unattended like this ”The post has gone viral since being posted online on Friday, with almost two million views.The woman has been blasted online for her ‘bad parenting’, with many thanking the driver for his sharp eyes.One woman wrote: “That is so scary! Thank God you saw her. That would have been absolutely awful. God bless you.”

title: philip hammond budget cash public money
story: Philip Hammond spoke yesterday for more than an hour. There were announcements on schools funding, defence, moving “from disposable to reusable cups across all beverage types” — even a tax break for public loos. More money for social care and Universal Credit.Shopkeepers will breathe a sigh of relief at a hefty cut to business rates.There were hints of more money for the police. Sun readers will also welcome the tax freezes on beer, spirits, cider and short-haul flights.But the big bucks — some £.billion of the £.billion extra the Government expects to spend come - — went to the NHS, fulfilling the Prime Minister’s summer promise to increase spending as a th birthday present to a health service creaking under the strain of an ageing population.The question, of course, was how the Chancellor was going to pay for it.Before the Budget, all sorts of grim possibilities had been floated.Extra taxes on white-van men, lower- ing the VAT threshold and tightening the rules about National Insurance contributions. Taxes on plastic cups . Taxes on pretty much anything, really.Perhaps the best thing the Chancellor did in his Budget, then, was say “No”.To almost all of it. For an hour or more, I waited for the sting in the tail — the bit where Fiscal Phil turned Hatchet Hammond.But it never came. In paying for his promises — and above all, the NHS — the Chancellor was helped by better-than-expected borrowing forecasts, which showed our economy’s remarkable record of creating jobs is still going strong.But he has also made a calculation that it is better to live with a small and manageable deficit than try to drag the finances back into surplus at the cost of higher taxes. And that voters will see through Labour’s promises to hike borrowing back to stratospheric levels in the name of a socialist transformation of the economy.He decided, in other words, people pay enough tax already.And he’s right. All too often in recent years, it has felt like the answer to every problem — at least from Whitehall’s point of view — is higher taxes and more interference.Hammond was never going to copy his tax-slashing Tory predecessor Nigel Lawson, who made it a point of principle to abolish a dferent tax with every Budget.But at least he drew a line in the sand, deciding it is better when hardworking people get to keep more of their own money.That ending austerity should not, and must not, mean higher tax bills. That hard work should mean hard cash in your pocket.Yes, Hammond — like every Chancellor since Gordon Brown — made too many fiddly little announcements.But he avoided the kind of whacking- great raid on taxpayers’ pockets so many were urging him towards.This doesn’t mean we are out of the woods. Britain’s growth prospects over the next half-decade are still extraordinarily sluggish.The outcome of the Brexit deal will drastically change the fiscal picture.In many ways, Hammond’s speech yesterday was a holding action ahead of the much bigger decisions to come.We still need much more radical action to kickstart growth and productivity. Despite the scale of the housing crisis, for example, there was only tinkering around the edges.But a large part of delivering that growth must involve making the economy more dynamic, more competitive and letting people keep more of their own money as a reward for their efforts — moving the country in the direction outlined by Philip Hammond, rather than the one sketched out by Jeremy Corbyn .The overall verdict on the Budget  The jokes were worse than expected but the numbers were better.More spending on the NHS, tax cuts for millions of voters and the worst ideas kept out of it.Yes, borrowing will be higher — but low enough to keep us out of the danger zone and far, far lower than under a Corbyn government.That is a menu Philip Hammond will be pretty happy with.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: philip hammond budget end of austerity
story: Three quarters of the Chancellor’s vast increase in cash to ministries will go to the NHS, to pay for its £bn a year boost announced by Theresa May last summer.But Treasury officials insisted even after health’s new money pile, there would still be inflation-linked rises for every department in next year’s Whitehall-wide spending review.Dubbing his Budget “a defining moment in this long hard journey”, Mr Hammond told MPs: “The era of austerity is finally coming to an end”.The massive splurge sparked critics’ fears that he would lose control of the deficit again.But Mr Hammond insisted that debt will continue to fall as a percentage of GDP in each of the next five years.And in a thinly veiled plea to Tory MPs to back any Brexit deal that the PM strikes, Mr Hammond also pledged to spent even moreBritain’s EU exit is smooth.The Chancellor conjured up the vision of a “double deal idend” as businesses start spending again at the same time as he releases £billion stashed away as a Brexit war chestit goes bad.The MoD was yesterday’s biggest winner, landing a total of £.billion more from the Chancellor this year and next.Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson was delighted with the win, as it meant he no longer has to make any capability cuts over the next  months.But a long-term solution to his ministry’s £billion blackhole over the next decade was delayed until the Whitehall-wide spending review, expected next summer.The extra defence cash will go on cyber, anti-submarine warfare capacity, and the next generation Dreadnought subs to carry the nation’s Trident nuclear deterrent.Mr Hammond said he was acting because the last year had thrown up “stark reminders of the scale, scope and complexity of the threats we face”.Local authorities struggling to fund OAP care will also be able to dip into a new £m nationwide pot unveiled by the Chancellor yesterday.And some of the NHS’s huge £billion of extra spending a year was also fleshed out, with £bn to be dedicated to mental health services – including a unit for it in every school and AE centre.Mr Hammond pleased Brexiteers by allocating another £million for no-deal Brexit preparations.He also confirmed he would carry out another Budget in the Springthere was no deal and a disorderly Brexit instead.Mr Hammond also unveiled £million more for counter-terror policing next year. Pleasing Home Secretary Sajid Javid.Angry Tory MPs who had threatened numerous rebellions over funding shortfalls were happy last night.Campaigning former Army officer-turned Tory MP Johnny Mercer dubbed the defence injection “good news” as it meant an end to “the madness of the proposed in year cuts”.But right of centre economist also expressed concern that Mr Hammond was throwing caution out of the window too early.The Institute of Economic Affairs’s Director General Mark Littlewood said: “In an attempt to signal the ‘end of austerity’, it appears this government has given up on deficit elimination.But Labour called the move “patronising” after Mr Hammond said it would help buy “that extra bit of kit”.And union boss Geoff Barton said many schools didn’t have enough cash for basic education needs, let alone extras.“It will be more than a quarter of a century since the government last balanced the books”.The austerity Chancellor George Osborne’s former chief of staff Rupert Harrison added: “The government was groping its way towards a sensible strategy, but the ‘end of austerity’ language raises expectations that can’t be met”.Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson was delighted with the boost, as it means he no longer has to make any capability cuts over the next  months.The extra defence cash will go on cyber, anti-submarine warfare capacity, and the next generation of Dreadnought subs to carry the nation’s Trident nuclear deterrent.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle prince harry auckland welly wanging
story: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex braved the rain in Auckland as they near the end of their tour Down Under.The Royal pair went head-to-head to hurl gumboots at a target, along with kids from the Trees in Survival group.They were pictured laughing as the Duchess stepped up to lob her pink and white polka dot welly, while Harry threw a blue boot.And it was the Duchesss team who won on the day - even though Harry managed to get his boot slightly closer to the target.Meghan looked classy wearing Muck Boot Company reign wellies, which sell for £.She also wore black J Crew jeans and a navy blue Karen Walker blazer - but slipped on a branded rain coat for the contest.Harry looked dapper in grey chinos, white shirt and a long brown overcoat.They are on a -day trip which has seen them travel to Australia, Fiji and Tonga, and they are now in New Zealand.In the afternoon, the pair took a tour of Viaduct Harbour in Auckland.Meghan held her growing baby bump as she wore a figure hugging tan Brandon Maxwell dress, long Burberry rain mac and nude heels.Harry changed into a petrol blue suit and blue suede shoes.Also known as welly hoying and boot throwing, welly wanging sees competitors take it in turns lob wellies at a target.The bizarre game originated in Englands West Country.Rules dfer depending on the country you are playing it in - for example, in Somerset the boot is filled with water before being thrown.Teppo Luoma, of Finland, holds the world record for the longest welly-wang - . metres .The World Welly Wanging Association HQ is in Upperthong UK. Meghan was presented with flowers by six-year-old Ghianna Angi as the couple arrive at Pillars.The charity operating across New Zealand that supports children who have a parent in prison through mentoring schemes.The crowd also handed her soft toys, flowers and a bag of slime.A brass band played the theme music from Meghans old show Suits and the crowd sang-a-long as the Duchess greeted well-wishers.But Meghan was careful not to acknowledge their cheeky musical cue, with royals keen for her to distance her image from her acting past.The mother and father-to-be later attended a reception hosted by prime minister Jacinda Ardern.Speaking before the reception at the Auckland War Memorial Museum, New Zealands PM said: Theres a real connection between particularly William and Harry in recent years so its nice to have been able to host them in such close proximity.When askedthe question of whether the Duke and Duchesss visit has changed views on New Zealand becoming a republic, Ms Ardern said: It just really doesnt come up as much.The only time it really comes up is, often off the back of visits, people tend to ask the question.What youll pick up from the New Zealand public is that there is a real affinity for the Queen and a real strength of feeling around members of the royal family, particularly given, in the wake of some of our disasters, that theyve been quick to respond and be present.Ms Ardern said had not shared any baby tips with Harry and Meghan - the PM gave birth to baby Neve in June - but that she admired the duchess for her work while pregnant.She said: Its just increased my respect for the role that shes playing at such an often tiring time.I have real empathy and I think shes incredible.Earlier today Meghan got her hands dirty, helped to plant a kowhai tree - a traditional flower she had sewn into her stunning wedding veil.Father-in-law Charles is sure to be impressed with her green-fingered eagerness.Their tour was unaffected as New Zealand was struck by a . magnitude earthquake  miles away.The final stop on the royal tour on Wednesday will be Rotorua, renowned for its geothermal activity with geysers and mud pools.Yesterday they came face-to-face with an orc from Lord of the Rings.

title: hammonds price freeze beer
story: The Chancellor announced a saving of p on a pint of beer, p on a pint of cider and a p on a bottle of scotch or gin.But he hit a bottle of wine with a p rise — and a price of a packet of fags will rise by more than five per cent.Super-strength low cost “white cider” was also excluded from the duty freeze but will instead by the subject of a new rate of tax from October next year.Mr Hammond also confirmed the freeze in fuel duty announced by Theresa May last month.The decision to freeze spirits duty saw off a rebellion by Scottish Tory MPs who have campaigned to protect the gangbuster whisky industry.And more than  Tory MPs had also warned the Chancellor off of a beer tax hike.Last night the British Beer  Pub Association, said: “Pub-goers across the UK will be toasting the Chancellor tonight following his decision to freeze beer duty.“This early Christmas present will save brewers, pubs and pub-goers £ million and secure upwards of , jobs that would have been lost had beer duty gone up.”But the Wine and Spirits Trade Association said the wine hike was “grossly unfair, unjustied and counter-productive”.SMOKERS were hit with a five per cent rise in tobacco duty — pushing many packs above £.The Chancellor added about p on a pack of  that already retailed at £. in the UK.Tax was raised at two per cent above inflation, with an additional one percentage point added to hand-rolling tobacco.Smokers rights group Forest called the rises “grossly unfair”.Director Simon Clark said: “The people hardest hit are those who can least afford it.”And tobacco bosses group the TMA said: “Tobacco taxes have increased by  per cent since . This will simply encourage more smokers to avoid paying UK tax by purchasing tobacco from abroad or via the black market.”Chief executive Miles Beale said wine has been the most lucrative alcoholic drink for the Treasury since it overtook beer in .He added: “The UK is the world’s biggest wine trading nation and, as such, deserves the Government’s support, not punishment.”Duty on tobacco products will continue to rise at two percentage points above retail price indexinflation, with an additional one percentage point added to hand rolling tobacco.Smokers advocacy group Forest said the hikes were “grossly unfair”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: fascists rally mussolini hometown predappio
story: Far-right militants have gathered in Predappio to mark Il Duce’s rise to power with the March on Rome.Around , blackshirts gathered in the Italian capital to demand the resignation of the then Prime Minister Luigi Facta on the night of October  to , .In the rally to mark this march, many can be seen giving the fascist salute, which is not outlawed in the country despite its past.In one image a group of men give a right-arm salute while holding a banner of Mussolini.Another picture shows a woman dressed in a baseball cap and t-shirt with the word “Auschwitzland” and an outline of the death camp on it.In a third a man appears to be dressed in a black World War II-era military unorm.The far right militants in Italy have been encouraged due to the country’s sht to the right with the rise of the populist, Eurosceptic and anti-immigration Five Star Movement and its blocking of a parliamentary bill which was aimed at banning fascist salutes and the sale of Mussolini memorabilia.Earlier this year the party, lead by Luigi Di Maio, became the largest single party in the countrys parliament.It secured . percent of the vote and  seats, not enough to secure an overall majority though and the party is largely dependent on the Lega Nord for support.Thousands travel to Mussolini’s birthplace every year and souvenir shops sell fascist-themed souvenirs like coffee mugs that have the slogans: Believe, Obey and Fight.Born on July , , Mussolini was the leader of the country’s Partito Nazionale Fascista– PNF.He became Prime Minister in  after the March on Rome and effectively became a dictator in  and ruled until .Mussolini became known as Il Duce .Initially Mussolini had joined the Socialist Partybut was expelled for supporting military intervention in the First World War.After the war his views focused on “revolutionary nationalism”.Following the Abyssinia Crisis in - he invaded Ethiopia which was widely condemned by the Western Powers but he got the backing of Germany’s leader Adolf Hitler.Hitler and Mussolini formed what was called the Rome-Berlin Axis and signed a treaty of co-operation.On June ,  Italy joined the Second World War, on the side of Germany.In October that year Mussolini sent Italian forces into Greece although it was unsuccessful and the counter-offensive pushed the forces back to Albania.Italy also suffered a humiliating defeat when it joined with Germany in launching an attack on the Soviet Union.Mussolini also suffered a defeat when the Axis Powers were crushed in North Africa..In July  the Grand Council of Fascism passed a motion of no confidence in Mussolini and on July  the king dismissed him as head of the government.He was held in custody until he was rescued by German troops.Mussolini then tried to flee the country with his mistress Clara Petacci to Switzerland but both were captured by communist partisans and executed by firing squad.His body was then taken to Milan was it was hung upside down at a petrol station to publicly confirm his death.The far-right Forza Nuova party had announced a march called the “March of Patriots” in Rome for October  but the Interior Minister Marco Minniti said any march would be illegal.Speaking in parliament in September he said that any event like that “clearly recall[ed] the birth of the fascist regime and would clearly contrast with the legal order.In response to the initial criticism, Forza Nuovas leader Roberto Fiore denied any fascist or nostalgic element to the march, and called it a walk for security.

title: after years of grim penny pinching budgets we must say nice one chancellor
story: Like the bumper tax cut for million workers, a year earlier than promised.The £billion NHS injection, the £billion bailout for defence, hundreds of millions for our pock-marked roads and hard-up schools. Another £.billion to iron out Universal Credit problems. A near five per cent hike in the minimum wage. A big, welcome cut in business rates for struggling firms.New ideas flowed: a levy on web giants’ UK revenues, potentially raising £million, is long overdue — though Philip Hammond must ensure the ­burden does not fall on online shoppers.There was major funding to help councils transform our hollowed-out High Streets, including turning vacant shops into homes. A huge increase in firms’ annual investment allowance will let them deduct from taxable profits up to £million spent on tools and machinery.Heathrow’s e-gates will now speed up entry for visitors from the US, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and Japan as well as Europe — a symbol of a global Britain open for business.Some bad ideas The Sun has criticised, including the proposed “latte levy” on plastic cups, were binned. Duty was frozen again on fuel, as well as beer.Even the OBR’s normally pessimistic forecasts were on Mr Hammond’s side. Growth is predicted to rise steadily, albeit too slowly. Unemployment is set to fall to its lowest in  years.We wish the Chancellor had outlined more radical, visionary low-tax measures. He will need them should Brussels shove us into a no-deal Brexit. But that gripe aside, what was not to like The Tories must not try to ape Corbyn’s £trillion spending fantasy. But it is not “Corbyn-lite” to spend billions fixing Britain’s most pressing problems, evenwe are still running a deficit.As for Corbyn himself, it was obvious he took in barely a word of the Budget.In his “response” he merely recited his normal scripted complaints, flubbing his words and shouting randomly, as is now traditional. He somehow contrives to make even this chaotic Government look like a model of competence.Budgets often unravel when acres of small print are finally scrutinised.But for now... nice one, Chancellor.ANGELA Merkel is a once-brilliant politician scuppered by an arrogant disregard for voters.For years she was admired worldwide. Then she flooded Germany with a million migrants, enraging the public, fuelling extremism and sealing her own downfall.Don’t expect Brussels to learn from it.Their contempt for citizens is even worse. And it will do for them too.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: woman ghost face photograph abandoned house
story: Kristie Ranieri, , was on a walk with husband Michael Sharf, , when they passed the dilapidated building in Lake Forest, Illinois, and stopped to take a look.It was the summer home of socialite Ginevra King, who had a two-year romance with author F Scott Fitzgerald and was his inspiration for The Great Gatsby.Kristie, of Lake Forest, says her husband spotted the apparent apparition of a female face when flicking through their pictures later that evening.The personal chef is convinced that the image of a woman staring out of the dormer window proves the socialite, who passed away in , haunts her former family estate.Kristie said: “I visit the house every year but I skipped it last year because it had been abandoned and had really gone to pot.“But this year, with the fall colours looking so beautul, I walked around it with my husband and took some pictures.“Michael was going through the pictures that night, zooming into the windows to seehe could see the interiors and that’s when he spotted her face.“We definitely got chills. Neither of us believed in ghosts but we were really freaked out.“I knew what Ginevra King looked like because I’m interested in local history and she grew up in this area.When I saw that picture, I immediately Googled her and we both agreed it has to be her.”The couple even ed to the -room mansion, built in , the next day to seethe face was still there.Kristie said: “We rushed back to seewe could spot her again but of course she was gone.”She now hopes to approach experts who evaluate pictures of the paranormal.She said: “I want to talk to some experts in this field and I want to let the local ghost hunters know.I imagine this will now become a spot on the ghost hunting trail.“I was a sceptic before but seeing that image, I know that it is her ghost looking down.”The mansion used to be part of the -acre estate that the King Family used as a summer home and called Kingdom Come Farm.It was sold to a developer in  who hopes to find a buyer for the home which has stood uninhabited for almost a decade.Fitzgerald visited King at the home in the summers of  and  but Ginevra broke off their romance in .The following year she married William Mitchell, the son of her father Charles G King’s business associate.Fitzgerald never forgot the slight and went on to model the character of Daisy Buchanan, Gatsby’s unattainable love interest, in his famous  novel on King.Ginevras father reportedly told Fitzgerald: “Poor boys shouldn’t think of marrying rich girls.”Although Fitzgerald did not include the line in his famous novel, it found its way into the  film adaptation of The Great Gatsby starring Mia Farrow and Robert Redford.

title: prince harry offers student job new zealand
story: Lucia Kennedy chatted to the Duke and Duchess of Sussex during an event at a café in Wellington focusing on youth mental health on Monday.The -year-old, who is studying a double degree in commerce and psychology at university, told Stuff: I said to Harry, I finish uni in two years, Id love to come and work for you.He said, Wed love to have you, just give us a yell when you come over, well sort it out.The student said shed celebrate the job offer by having dinner with her flatmates.Lucia, who describes herself as a happiness entrepreneur, was part of a  minute session at the Maranui cafe to discuss youth mental health.She founded the Take A Chance Project, which offers coaching and mentor programmes for young people, after losing friends and her family home in the Christchurch earthquake when she was just .Lucia said: I saw Harrys face light up when he heard about counselling offered to the defence team and New Zealand military personnel.He was really impressed and happy to hear that, I think.During his time at the cafe, Harry spoke about his own struggles with mental health admitting that it took him years to confront his own inner turmoil after losing his mum Diana, Princess of Wales, in a car crash aged .He said: It took me about three or four years to start the journey and then after that you still have to find the right people to speak to.Harry praised Voices of Hope for their  viral video Dear Suicidal Me, which features young people who have overcome mental health issues reading their own suicide notes.The couple heard the video saved the le of a -year-old young girl in Canada.Her mother contacted us and said that her daughter was planning to take her le but then saw the video and went to speak to her instead, said Jazz Thornton, co-founder of Voices of Hope.It saved her le.Harry said: Its amazing what you have done.I think anyone who has overcome mental health problems often go out of their own way to help others.

title: businesswoman caught swerving all over the road when double the alcohol limit told cops she didnt know her colleagues had been topping up her drink on works night out
story: Rachel Hind, , was stopped by cops when they saw her Audi A swerving onto the wrong side of the road after she left an Italian restaurant.Hind had just treated  colleagues to dinner, but on her way home at am police officers had to take evasive action in their patrol van to avoid hitting Hinds car.When whey asked her to get out of her car, the registered nurse struggled to get her keys out of the ignition.She was also staggering in her high heels with slurred speech, glazed eyes and her breath smelling heavily of alcohol, the court heard.It emerged the mum-of-two had been drinking Prosecco, gin and tonic and double vodkas with cola during one of her regular evenings out to thank their employees before heading to her £.million home in High Legh, near Knutsford, Cheshire.At Manchester Magistrates Court Hind admitted drink driving but tried to argue against disqualication claiming she thought she was sober at the time.She added that she did not realise a colleague had unwittingly topped up her drinks throughout the evening in the belief she was getting a taxi home.She claimed she was only swerving around in the road as she was attempting to avoid potholes. JPs banned her for  months and fined her £, with costs of £.The incident occurred at .am on June  this year after Hind had left the Italian Job restaurant in Urmston after the party had spent up to six hours eating and drinking.John Richards prosecuting said: The police evidence says she was swerving around.She was unsteady on her feet, her eyes were glazed and her speech was slurred. She was staggering and her breath stank of alcohol and she needed help into the police van.The crown say it would have been patently obvious to her that she was over the limit. You might think it’s strange that she didn’t realise her Prosecco had been topped up. In a short period of time, the glass goes from half full to full - how did she not realise that In terms of the vodka and cola, evenit was the case that you’re dealing with single shots, you’re going to knowit’s got alcohol in it. But we are talking about doubles here. The crown says that it doesn’t stack up that she didn’t realise.Tests showed Hind, who specialises in end-of-le care at her two care homes, blew a reading of  microgrammes of alcohol in  millilitres of breath. The legal limit is mg.She told the hearing: Every quarter of the year I take the staff out for a meal and drinks and to say thank you. I take them to an Italian restaurant and they have an open bar. I just pay the bill and let them have what they want.I would always drive there and drive home. Very occasionally, I would get a taxi but on that day I drove. I was on call that night which means I am in charge of running the night sht. I ordered a single gin and tonic.I always would have a gin and tonic and maybe a glass of ProseccoI was having a three-course meal.She added: There were jugs of water all along the table which I had some of. I also had about four to five glasses of coke and I also had a glass of Prosecco with my main meal which was at about ish. I felt fine. I didn’t feel drunk, I felt fine to drive - I didn’t think I was taking a risk. I gave my colleague a lt home, which I wouldn’t have doneI felt drunk.But the road was full of potholes. It did occur to me that I hope the police don’t think I am a drunk driver because I am swerving to avoid the potholes. I have had four punctures in two years on that car from potholes.But I didn’t think I caused the police van to swerve. The police woman told me to open my car and I told her that I needed to shut the car door to turn off the engine - I did struggle to get the car keys out when I did this.I told the officer from the very beginning that I had been drinking, but it was only one gin and tonic and a glass of Prosecco over the course of a three course meal. I struggled out of the police van, but I was wearing high heels and I don’t normally wear them.I had a terrible row with my husband about it afterwards. I was disappointed in myself and I went into a spell of depression. I couldn’t tell anybody at work about it because I am their employer and I am supposed to be an example to them.She claimed a colleague Amanda Jackson later confessed to topping up her drinks during the evening during a heart-to-heart meeting and added: She went white in the face and said ‘I’m sorry, but I topped your drinks up that night.’She didn’t know I was driving home and she told me that she had been giving me drinks. She said she topped up my Prosecco once and that she had put Vodka and Cokes on the table.If I am drinking alcohol, it’s only gin and tonic that I am drinking which I know the smell and taste of. I don’t drink vodka. I have never been a vodka and cola - it just tasted of cola.Retrospectively, I can see now that I was drunk but at no point did I feel over the limit at the time, I was talking to my colleague all the way home in the car.My cousin died after being hit by an articulated lorry and my best friends nephew was also hit by a drunk driver. I haven’t drink driven until this incident where I unknowingly got into my car while over the limit and drove.Work colleague Miss Jackson admitted unwittingly getting doubles for her boss.She said: I made sure that the drinks and food were going to the right people. I went to the bar a couple of times and ordered about four vodka and cokes each time and I just brought them to the table and put them down there.I saw she was drinking coke but I didn’t realise she was supposed to be drinking normal coke.I was just going around the table filling the glasses up. I filled them all up.When she told me what happened I said ‘Oh my god, I am so sorry I bought you some drinks and I didn’t know you weren’t drinking.’It’s all my fault and she’s in all this trouble and I didn’t know she wasn’t drinking. She is my boss and she is amazing at what she does, and I feel terrible and will take the consequences.I am not going to lie, I was quite drunk that night - about a  .”Hinds lawyer Miss Stephanie Varle said: “In the UK, a lot of people drink a small amount of alcohol and drive.You have heard that she reasonably believed that she drank a gin and tonic and a glass of Prosecco and was safe to drive home. She did go out and consume some alcohol, which the law permits her to do - but she didn’t notice her drink had been topped up.This is a woman who works  hours and was on call on that evening. I submit that when she was moving around, she would not notice an odourless drink. She was driving at a normal speed and was simply trying to circumnavigate the potholes in the road.The alcohol limit does unfortunately permit people to lawfully get behind the wheel of a car after some drink.But JP Edward Tasker, said: Having heard all the evidence, we don’t accept that the defendant didn’t know that the drinks didn’t have alcohol in them.

title: uk weather forecast today storm adrian hurricane oscar
story: The Met Office is warning that rainfall from Storm Adrian will lash England this morning after causing chaos with devastating floods in Italy and incredible rainfall in the Alps.East Anglia and Kent are expected to be hit the hardest by Storm Adrian, but coastal areas in Yorkshire and Lincolnshire could also be affected today.But unfortunately the wind and rain wont end there as Hurricane Oscars mph winds rage across the Atlantic towards Britain on Friday.Met Office meteorologist Alex Burkill said: Adrains brought a lot of unsettled weather to Europe like intense thunderstorms, but from our point of view its bringing a bit of rain to Eastern parts of England.In the UK, weve got some rain affecting the Eastern and South Eastern parts of England this morning and through today.The National Hurricane Center in America is warning that Oscar will cause le-threatening swells and rip-tides in Bermuda on Wednesday.Then its effects will be felt in Britain by the end of the week - but the the violent storm is proving dangerously dficult to predict for weather experts.Alex explains: Oscars always been a tricky one and theres always been a lot of uncertainty regarding it.And at the moment, the most likely track will actually take us a little bit further North than we were thinking before.This means that torrential rain and extremely powerful winds are expected to hit the Western Isles and Highlands of Scotland, where gusts of mph or stronger are very likely on Friday and into the weekend.But because of the volatile nature of the storm, Brits are advised to look out for severe weather warnings later in the week as the track of Oscar becomes clearer.Alex added: We probably arent going to be issuing any warnings today for it, because theres quite a lot of uncertainty and the track could change again and it could come further South in which case well be changing our story because then it will affect more people.If the track that were forecasting at the moment is what happens, then warnings would be required.For today, there will be rain in the East of the UK with a few showers where and some sunny spells, with highs of around C in Devon and Cornwall.But tonight will be chilly as patches of low cloud and frost set in widely across the country as temperatures are expected to fall to -C.Last night was the coldest night of autumn so far when the mercury plunged all the way down to -.C in Sennybridge in Wales.Wednesday will also have showers in the North and West of Britain, while the South East remains dry and could reach heights of C.Thursday will see persistent rain across central and south eastern parts of England and lighter showers in Northern Ireland and Scotland.And Friday will start with a good deal of sunshine before turning very wet and windy in the North West s the effects of Oscar strike Britain.

title: giant rat invasion foot long bristol
story: The woman, who asked not to be named, spotted the giant rodents scurrying along her turfed balcony in the Lockleaze area of Bristol.The mum said the first-floor balcony of her housing association home had become infested along with neighbours properties.She told the Bristol Post: Something needs to be done to cure this problem for good. They have chewed through the walls of the building to get across to each property.My children have noticed them but theyre a bit young to understand.She said she now wont let her children - aged one, four and five - play outside.Bristol-based United Communities housing association said the entire city has been suffering from rat infestations.Jayme Whittleson, control manager at the housing association, said: This was first reported to us on Facebook and straight away we attended.The bins were in a very reasonable order, they werent overflowing.Rats are an issue all over the city.This summers heatwave brought a plague of giant rats across the UK.Experts say there could now be as many as  million rats across Britain.We pay for your stories! title: budget 2018 public spending rise no deal brexit philip hammond
story: The Chancellor said he would increase funding for services in an emergency Budget following a No Deal scenario.And he denied that yesterdays Budget giveaway was laying the ground for a snap General Election - insisting he just wanted to give the country good news.Mr Hammond yesterday cut taxes for million Brits as he announced he was boosting spending by £billion over the coming years.The Chancellor has previously suggested the end of austerity could be delayedwe quit the EU without a Brexit deal.But speaking this morning, he admitted his plans would involve higher public spending to help the economy remain stable.Mr Hammond told the BBC: If the economy suffers a shock - and a No Deal Brexit is an example of a shock... we will deal with it in the usual way.Very often a shock to the economy actually requires a boost to spending in the short term to support demand and to keep the economy going.He added thatBritain and the EU do strike a good deal, spending could rise anyway as the economy grows.Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell accused Mr Hammond of handing out tax cuts in order to buy off voters ahead of a possible snap election.He said: The Tories usually do this. If a General Election is coming, what theyll do is theyll splash out some money and thenthey win the election they then start cutting it back again.Mr Hammond denied trying to bribe the electorate, saying: What we are preparing for is Britains future.Weve now turned a corner and we are able to give Britain a bit of good news.He also insisted he is still hoping to balance the Budget despite cutting taxes and increasing spending.A snap opinion poll shows that most Brits back the Chancellors decision to turn on the spending taps after eight years of austerity.Some  per cent said boosting public services should be Mr Hammonds priority, with only  per cent calling for more deficit reduction.But critics today accused the Budget of squeezing poorer workers and forcing the burden of austerity on to women.The left-wing Resolution Foundation thinktank said  per cent of the tax cuts will go to wealthier families.Director Torsten Bell said: Income tax cuts announced yesterday will overwhelmingly benefit richer households, with almost half of the long-term gains going to the top ten per cent of households.On public services, the NHS saw a big-spending boost - but unprotected departments still have further cuts pencilled in.And senior Labour MP Yvette Cooper claimed  per cent of the impact of austerity had fallen on women - adding: The gender gap in the Tories tax and benefit policies is getting worse.

title: boy crystal meth seizure halloween galion ohio
story: Braylen Carwell, from Galion, Ohio, began shaking when he ed from collecting candy on Sunday and was rushed to hospital.While it was initially thought his sweets has been tainted with meth, the boy insists the only thing he put in his mouth before the seizure was a pair of plastic vampire teeth.Police have sent the novelty dentures, which he was given while out trick-or-treating, away to be tested.Investigators also retrieved the sweets which Braylen had been given and collected them as evidence after his parents had thrown them out.His mother Julia Pence described the moment her son began having a seizure.She told Fox : “The left side of his face was just droopy and then he fell and then he couldn’t move his left arm.“And he didn’t know where he was, he didn’t know what he was doing.”Julia says the little boy is still feeling the effects from the powerful drug.She said: “You can tell he is still coming down from it because one minute he is all hyper and the next minute he is tired.The distraught mother admitted to cops that she and the boy’s father are recovering drug addicts, reports TV.But she insists they have both been sober for sometime and strongly denied having anything to do with Braylen’s positive drugs test.She said: “Im not covering up the truth. Im just speaking the truth of what happened to my son, yesterday.“Nobody in my family ordads family would drug my children.The five-year-old’s dad said hed taken his kids trick-or-treating for about two hours on Sunday afternoon.He said his son had only had a couple of pieces of candy and was playing with some sort of fake teeth, according to police.Police Chief Brian Saterfield said: “Right now, there’s nothing specic. We need to narrow it down to seethere was in fact something that was tainted.”Cops are urging parents to check their children’s sweet and any other items they are given during Halloween trick-or-treating.

title: photos streets britain colourful crazy side life blighty
story: Paramedic Chris Porsz walked hundreds of miles around  cities since  taking quirky pictures of everyday le, from pensioners and party-goers to buskers to bikers.The -year-old from Peterborough has now published a book, Streets of Britain, featuring more than  pictures from UK cities.The photos offer a unique snapshot of le in Britain today, with pictures of people singing, screaming and scooting.Chris said: I have walked many miles over the years, unsure exactly what I am looking for but I just know when I see it and then snap!.Its usually something surreal, bizarre, someone a bit eccentric who stands out from the madding crowd or everyday people caught up in some humorous interaction.Chris caught the photography bug after buying a camera when his first child Simon was born in .He began walking the streets of his home town of Peterborough for inspiration and quickly developed a passion for street photography. He later decided to hone his craft by visiting other cities.Chris said: Some cities were full of characters, such as Brighton, and it was easy to get lots of good pictures, but others I had to keep ing to until I got what I needed. Ive tried to capture a snapshot of a day in each of the cities.He added that sometimes it would be frustratingsomeone walked in front of the camera at the wrong time or he missed the moment, but other pictures would then make up for it.He added: My near misses would fill another book, but any moments of dejection and self-doubt are soon forgotten when I see a man in Newcastle wearing a pink suit and a horses head, or a pensioner walking around Nottingham with an owl on his arm, as you do.I cannot resist snapping the drunken hens and their inevitable here I am, tadar! pose. Every town too has its fire and brimstone brigade so I just wait patiently for a sinner to come along to make a lucky juxtaposition.Chris said his work as a paramedic at Peterborough City Hospital helped with his street photography as he was able to reassure complete strangers and react instinctively to the unexpected.Sometimes Chris would talk to the subjects of his photos and discover an even more exciting story - the front cover of his book is one of his favourites.He explained: The lady was about  and lived in Peterborough and was describing how as a young girl on Bonfire Night she set off a rocket and it went through the window of a policemans house and burnt it down.Although it looks like she is giving the finger, she is actually putting her finger up to demonstrate the rocket going in the air.

title: the last budget before brexit but a deal hasnt happened yet
story: The deficit should have been closing in on zero. Instead, it is left at a persistent #bn or so.So the government retrospectively funded the promise made by the PM for the biggest ever cash increase in NHS funding, but did so without raising taxes.In fact it cut them a bit by accelerating to this coming April, the rise in basic rate and higher rate income tax thresholds to #, and #, respectively.At the time of that announcement in summer, even at the Conservative Party conference, the Chancellor had suggested that these spending rises would be at least partly funded by tax rises.Not so, according to these numbers. But they may yet materialise on the other side of the Brexit fog.In that respect - the extra spending on the NHS, not funded by a tax rise - there was an end to austerity politics. But Mr Hammond was pointed in claiming austerity was coming to an end, rather than actually over. The government has calculated that there is no prize for a cash surplus.The claim about austerity itself was more debatable.The expected "fiscal envelope" for the spending review was conspicuous by its absence. title: theresa may budget is not paving the way for a general election
story: In the early months of , Downing Street consistently rejected suggestions Mrs May was considering calling a snap election.That April the PM did exactly that, with the Conservatives losing their parliamentary majority in the June election and remaining in office as a minority government.Most would expect Mrs May to have been chastened by that experience, but Mr Hammonds budget on Monday has led some to speculate about the prospect of another poll as Britain prepares for le outside the European Union.As well as the PM pouring cold water on the speculation, Mr Hammond has played down the prospect. He told Sky News: "Ive heard some commentators making this observation, but thats not how Ive approached the budget."Ive approached this budget in terms of delivering to the British people a clear view of the better times that are ahead as our economy and public finances turn the corner."Amid pressure to back up Mrs Mays recent pledge that the end of austerity is in sight, the chancellor announced a #bn loosening of the purse strings on Monday.This included income tax breaks for  million voters, help with business rates for the high street, more money for the governments controversial Universal Credit programme and a pledge to increase public spending in the years to come.Mr Hammond told Sky News he was able to turn the spending taps on because the public finances are "in a much better shape than theyve been for many years".,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey"" data-targeting-"" data-tag"" data-component-name"sdc-site-mpu" aria-label"Advertisement" id"mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance""

But as always, the devils in the detail. Once you get past the bad jokes, the shiny baubles and the claims that austerity is over - all thats left is the small print. And guess what  Some of it will leave you and your family worse off. The Department for Work and Pensions is being expected to cut its budget from poundbn to pound.bn in   . The Ministry of Justice is being cut from pound.bn to poundbn. And the housing and communities section of Whitehall is being cut from pound.bn to pound.bn. That’s despite a welfare crisis, a prisons crisis and a housing crisis. Not only did he resist any call to tax plastic cups. His big signature move - a tax on packaging that doesn’t have at least % recycled plastic - will only come in April . He made no mention of the date in his speech - we had to find it in the small print. Environmental Audit Committee chair Mary Creagh blasted: This speaks volumes about the Treasury’s priorities. As China, Vietnam and Thailand close their doors on Britain’s plastic waste the chancellors response is keep calm and carry on.”  According to the OBR forecast Google and other online giants could pay a mere poundm each under Hammonds new tax. Labour said the figure was “a pittance for these massive international companies” They said the percentage of tax paid by the big five tech giants had halved since . The new tax won’t come into force until  at which time the tech giants will start to enjoy a % cut in their corporation tax rate. Tom Watson, shadow Secretary of State for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport, said: “The lack of ambition in this announcement is derisory.” . … And it raises even less than we thought  If you thought the poundm raised from the Digital Services Tax didn’t seem like much, then don’t look at the back of the Budget book. It shows poundm a year is only what it’ll raise in . Next year it raises…. poundmillion. And in   it only raises poundmillion. . Crack cocaine of gambling stakes will stay above pound for another year  Campaigners blasted a six-month delay to cutting stakes on fixed-odds betting terminalsto pound. The move to slash maximum stakes on the “crack cocaine of gambling” from pound had been expected to come into force next April. But the Budget small print revealed the move will not take place until October. The Campaign for Fairer Gambling said it was “unacceptable”. Labour’s Carolyn Harris, who chairs Parliament’s cross-party group on FOBTs, was “appalled” at the “wholly unjustiable” delay. But a Treasury source said: “It’s clearly a judgement call. This we think strikes the right balance.”  Hammond announced an extra pound million for struggling schools to pay for “the little extras” they can’t afford. Many parents will have breathed a sigh of relief at the news, after getting begging letters from their kids’ teachers, asking for money to pay for such extravagances as pens, books and toilet paper. But they’ll be disappointed. The money is “capital spending”, ringfenced for building maintenance and purchasing equipment. That means schools will be allowed to buy iPads with the extra cash, but not pens and paper.  The Sovereign Grant - the money paid by the government to support the Queen in her royal duties is going up. Again. Last year the figure was .m - this year it’ll go up to an eye-watering pound. million. The size of the grant is usually % of the government’s income from Crown Estates. But last year she got a  year boost to % to pay for essential refurbishment of Buckingham Palace.  The government is set to introduce a tax on heated tobacco for the first time. The products will be taxed at the same rate as hand rolling tobacco from April . Note: This article originally stated the tax would also apply to vaping fluid. This is not the case. We are happy to correct the error. Duty on rolling tobacco amounts to around pound for the smallest, g packs.  Tory ministers have finally admitted they’re delaying Universal Credit, the small print reveals. The rollout of the hated six-in-one benefit will officially end in December  - the ninth delay after its last end date of March . And it may only finish in June , because the Office for Budget Responsibility “assumes” it will take six months longer than the Department for Work and Pensionssays. Just weeks ago, the DWP was refusing to confirm any delay to the Mirror. Delaying the rollout will actually save the DWP poundbillion - because thanks to a pound.bn-a-year package of help, it’s now “more expensive than the legacy system would have been”, the OBR declared. There’s also a suggestion that the money will be saved because, by delaying UC, less will be handed over to claimants in transition payments.  The Office For Budget Responsibility admits No Deal Brexit will have a “severe” impact. “If an agreement is not reached in time, it could have a severe short-term impact on demand and supply in the economy,” it says. “It is next to impossible to calibrate this sort of scenario because of the lack of precedent.” Philip Hammond announced another poundmillion in no-deal Brexit preparations, taking the total to pound.billion. The Chancellor boasted of “firepower to intervene”the economy needs more support in coming months - with poundbillion of “headroom” to deploy. Labour’s Chris Leslie, of the People’s Vote campaign, claimed: “There is no Brexit idend, only years of extended pain.” . … And the Brexit orce bill may have hit poundbillion  Again, this is one from the independent OBR, not the Budget document itself. The experts forecast that the Brexit orce bill could hit poundbn, much higher than the poundbn the government has claimed. It’s been revised up because of a weaker pound-euro exchange rate, and changes to contribution formulas and timetables. Best for Britain chief Eloise Todd said: Far from the fantasy millions promised by Brexiters, it has become increasingly clear that Britain will be facing a Brexit deficit.” . A controversial Tory home buying scheme is being reopened, and it’s costing poundbillion  You’d think a package of help for first-time buyers costing almost poundbillion might have been mentioned in the Budget speech. But nope - you have to delve into the documents to find the Help to Buy equity loan scheme is being reopened for two years from April . The scheme was previously slammed for helping buyers who were already well-off and allowing a five-year “time bomb” of fees to build up. This time it will be available only to first-time buyers - correcting a major flaw in the old scheme - but there are still some elements of unfairness. Londoners will be able to use it to get a home worth pound,, while in the North East it’s only available on homes worth pound,. And the scheme’s enormous cost on its own will attract attention.  We’ve found this one not in the Budget itself, but the report from the Office for Budget Responsibility. It says capital spending - long-term one-off hits on building projects and the like - has been cut, and the Treasury hasn’t spelt it out. The OBR says: “Departmental capital spending has also been cut from - onwards, a decision that does not appear on the Treasury’s scorecard of policy measures.”

title: john mcdonnell philip hammond gave
story: NewsopinionJohn McDonnell: Philip Hammond gave a broken promise budget, failing to end austerityBy choosing to cut rather than invest, Tories have failed to fix the weaknesses of the economy, says the Shadow ChancellorShareCommentsByJohn McDonnellShadow Chancellor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsopinion "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPeople will not put up with austerity any more, and the pressure is on Hammond to end it.But today he gave a broken-promise Budget, failing to end austerity, which was always a political choice. For more than eight years the Tories have given huge tax giveaways to the few while driving our public services into crisis. By choosing to cut rather than invest, Tories have failed to fix the weaknesses of the economy: low growth, low investment, low pay.Now, their approach to Brexit is putting it at risk. Tories have announced the end of austerity three times and never delivered. Much more is needed to start undoing the damage caused by cuts since . The poundbillion promised for the NHS is “simply not enough”, according to the independent Health Foundation, and can’t come at the expense of other public services.Local councils faces a funding gap of pound.billion by . Local services are at breaking point. School funding has been cut by %. Universal credit is pushing families into poverty. UC will leave the poorest families pound a month worse off, yet % of post- social security cuts are to come. Tories have spent more time arguing with themshyselves than negotiating with the EU. Labour will negotiate a Brexit deal that respects the referendum result whilst protecting jobs and rights at work. Labour will rebuild our economy for the many and not the few.

The Shadow Chancellor revealed he will not reverse Budget plans to make Income Tax allowances more generous in April . The move, unveiled by Chancellor Philip Hammond yesterday, will lt the tax-free allowance to pound, - saving anyone who earns more than that pound a year. But the p tax rate threshold is also being raise to pound, - saving the richest % of Brits a further pound a year. And a p rate would apply to earnings above pound,. Labour mayor of Greater Manchester Andy Burnham attacked Mr McDonnells pledge, saying: At a loss to understand why we are doing this. But the Shadow Chancellor said his key aim was to make sure the lowest paid get a decent wage. Mr McDonnell suggested the Tories were wanting to splash some money ahead of an imminent general election. But Theresa May told journalists today: We are not preparing for another general election. That would not be in the national interest.

title: philip hammonds brexit blindness mirror
story: NewsopinionPhilip Hammonds Brexit blindness: Mirror Politics morning briefingThe Budget failed on two counts: it increased inequality and it failed to offer a bold agenda for post-Brexit BritainShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  OCT NewsopinionThe congratulations could be short lived "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email If there was a phrase which will come to define yesterday’s Budget it was Philip Hammond’s handing poundmillion for schools to buy “the little extras they need.” The Chancellor has a reputation for political deafness but this was especially insensitive. The little extras headteachers need include not having to close their schools early, not having to cancel music and swimming lessons, not having to lay off teaching assistants and not having to beg parents for items such as toilet paper and stationery. Hammond’s choice of words pointed to a deeper problem. It implied that teachers and parents should be grateful for his largesse. But when you have put someone in hospital, you should not be surprisedthe patient then takes umbrageyou come round with a bunch of grapes and words of comfort. The Resolution Foundation think tank delivered its verdict on the Budget this morning and found it was deeply regressive. The Tories like to spin the raising of the income tax threshold as evidence of how they are helping the just about managing but it is a tax cut which is skewed towards the better off and does nothing for the five million people who earn too little to pay the tax.According to the Resolution Foundation, % of the income tax cuts announced yesterday will go to the top half of earners. The richest tenth of households are set to gain  times as much in cash terms next year from the income tax and benefits giveaways in the Budget as the poorest tenth of households . The small print tells a dferent narrative to that presented by the Chancellor. Once you strip away the increase in NHS spending then there is almost nothing for other departments. Even the extra pound.billion for the universal credit is offset by the poundbillion of welfare cuts being imposed by the Tories. Hammond framed his Budget as an example of how the Conservatives were balancing the ending of austerity with continued fiscal discipline. This was a sleight of hand when the figures show the strictures will remain in place for several years to come. The giveaways masked a bigger issue: the Chancellor has limited room to manoeuvre until Brexit is resolved. Everything is predicated upon Theresa May securing a deal.

story: NewsPhilip Hammond SNAPS in TV clash with Susanna Reid over utterly insulting schools cash in the BudgetThe Tory claimed his fund - worth just £k per primary or £k per secondary - was supposed to be a "nice gesture" as he faced furyShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video philip-hammond-angry-budget-clash-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChancellor Philip Hammond squirmed on live TV today as he was blasted over his utterly insulting promise of poundm for schools. The Tory claimed his fund - worth poundk per primary or poundk per secondary this year - would help buy the little extras teachers need. But it comes after years of cuts and pleas by head teachers for supplies as basic as pens and paper. Today the Chancellor told ITVs Good Morning Britain “I just thought that would be a nice gesture” so schools could buy a whiteboard, buy a couple of computers. He insisted schools could get more funds in next years spending review and it’s nothing to do with mainstream schools funding - it was simply a little extra.  But Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell said people were really angered by the remark. And GMB host Susanna Reid told him: What is happening in schools where theyre considering shorter weeks. They cant buy essentials! The Chancellor snapped: Frankly I reject that. Frankly I reject that. Schools funding will be dealt with in the spending review.  We put pound.bn additional money into schools funding last year to protect per pupil spending. What I did yesterday was nothing to do with that process - i was simply giving back a little bit of the money weve saved this year so schools can buy the odd little piece of kit that they need. I think thats a nice gesture. Many of the schools I know would be very happy to have pound, or even pound, to buy a whiteboard, buy a couple of computers, whatever it is. The money, announced in yesterdays Budget speech, has been allocated as capital spending. Capital funds are ringfenced for building maintenance and purchasing equipment.  That means schools will be allowed to buy iPads with the extra cash, but not pens and paper. And its been noted the money hes set aside for schools is tens of millions less than has been allocated to fix potholes. Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said that while the announcement was welcome, schools needed more. Shadow Education Secretary Angela Rayner added: It is utterly insulting to parents and teachers for the Chancellor to talk about little extra. School budgets have been cut by billions and head-teachers are begging parents for money for basic supplies like books and stationery.
