story: NewsHundreds queue in street to see incredible secret paintings discovered in pensioners home after he diedEric Tuckers massive painting collection was discovered by relatives in Warrington, Cheshire when they went to clear out his home after he died at the age of ShareCommentsByPhoebe Jobling:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video erik-tuckers-brother-says-no-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailUnskilled labourer Eric Tucker left a secret unseen legacy of artworks worthy of LS Lowry when he died at the home he lived in for virtually all his le. Unbeknown to his family, the ex-boxer who left school at  without qualication braved arthritis to create  oil and water colours in his front room over a seven decade period depicting working class le in his hometown. Rather than offering them for sale or exhibition, Eric kept his works out of public view - and instead stacked them around his unassuming end terraced property including his airing cupboard, in his shed and on top of his wardrobes. The massive painting collection was only discovered by relatives after the bachelor who lived alone in Warrington, Cheshire passed away last July aged  and they went to clear out his home.  Most of the pictures feature Lowry-type scenes from smoky pubs, tumbledown terraced streets and factories and showing flat capped locals with their wives. There are also several paintings of clowns, following on from Eric’s love of the circus as a child and portraits of his parents. Now Erics former home is to temporarily turned into a free art gallery for one weekend only which will display  of his paintings in an exhibition entitled  Years of Unseen Art. Younger brother Tony, , said: We did know Eric had a passion for art but never realised he had hoarded a huge collection in his home. He was a very modest man who never talked up his skills and despite doing sketches in his local he appeared to everyone just to be an ordinary Joe.  “Now all of the family have been wonderful, and we’ve all worked together in the hope that we will do justice to Erics work justice and get him the recognition he so richly deserves. We’re just sad that he isnt alive to see this all happen.” Eric the oldest of three children was born at the property in  and left school in  when he was just . He took up boxing and served four years in the Royal Horse Guards in Germany before working for local building contractors Arthur Monk in Warrington. His brother added: Eric didn’t do very well at school. He didn’t like being organised or people telling him what to do but he was intelligent and creative. He was known for having a love of boxing but he also had a passion for art too, “Despite having arthritis for most of his le, he never stopped painting. I’d call round to the house and find him painting on the front parlour. He never had any art training, but he was very committed. He was very modest. Painting wasn’t a hobby, it was his le.” Eric often drank in local pubs and working mens clubs and his paintings were often based on barroom scenes. Tony added: “Whenever he was in the pub, he would sketch on scraps of paper, drawing people in pubs across Warrington and Manchester. He especially loved Manchester in the s.  “Eric was a socialist and felt the most comfortable around ordinary working people and that they had the richest lives. He believed that people should always look out for one another. He had no formal art training beyond a sign writing apprenticeship but his knowledge and appreciation of painting was extensive – and his opinions on the subject were totally valid. He did get some offers to exhibit or buy his work but for some reason he refused as he did not want his paintings given away. Sadly his arthritis eventually prevented him from holding a paint brush but he did say he wanted his paintings to be seen after he was gone. We just assumed it would be a few pieces - but not . They were stacked up all around his house in his shed and on top of wardrobes. Im sure he will be delighted to learn his work will get a great deal of recognition. The exhibition will open from October  to  at Erics home Number , King George Crescent, Warrington, WA SH.

title: meghan markle cant keep hands
story: NewsWhy Meghan Markle cant keep her hands off her little baby bump - according to a midweThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex are expecting their first child in the Spring of ShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsMeghan Markle cant keep her hands off her baby bump "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNews broke of Meghan Markles pregnancy on the first day of her royal tour overseas with husband Prince Harry. The royal couple arrived in Australia glowing and ever since that moment the public have been keeping a keen eye on Meghans growing bump. People have showered the parents-to-be with gts for their unborn child and taken delight at hearing Harry, , open up about becoming a parent and discussing their little bump. Hes also recently revealed whether hes hoping to have a boy or a girl.  But more than this theres one thing thats really captured the attention of royal fans -the fact that no matter where she is, the Duchess simply cant stop touching and cradling her stomach. We think its totally adorable, but we cant help wondering why shes doing it  Thankfully a midwe has shared the answer. Lesley Gilchrist co-founder of My Expert Midwe explained to MailOnline that its a perfectly natural impulse no matter the size of the bump, to instinctively protect her unborn baby.  She revealed that an expectant mother may touch their bump anytime as they navigate the changes in the body and experience new sensations. Although most women will start to feel their baby move by around - weeks, some women may feel this sooner, says Lesley. Flutterings are the first sensations that are felt. However gas movement through the gut feels similar and this may cause an instinctive, involuntary touching of the stomach. It’s not uncommon for women at a similar stage to the Duchess of Sussex to feel those sensations.  She added: Those feelings of your baby moving are extremely special for women. It is such an amazing time. However not everyone is aware of this, and many people on social media have branded Meghans actions staged. One Twitter user wrote: Im not sureits a natural thing to do when pregnant or whether its a little bit staged. Another commented: Sick of the sight of Meghan Sparkle touching that non existent baby bump in every picture! #Embarrassing  A third added: All of a sudden Meghan has started locking her hands right on her tummy. Yeah, the world knows youre pregnant. Dont over-do it. But others were quick to come to her defense. I think it’s sad that people are questioning Meghan’s sincerity surrounding her bump. I once had a baby growing inside me, I can remember feeling a protection of it regardless of it only being a bean. I lost that baby. Touching my tum was the only connection I ever had to it, said someone .

title: mums insides hardening like stone
story: NewsMums insides are hardening like stone as deadly disease causes her heart, lungs and eyes to solidyEXCLUSIVE: Grace Ndajoki, from London, is bravely calling for more awareness of her auto-immune disease as she faces a “hopeless" prognosisShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video mum-whose-organs-hardening-like-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mums insides are hardening like stone as a rare, deadly disease causes her heart, lungs, skin and even eyes to solidy.Grace Ndajoki, from London, was diagnosed with the auto-immune condition scleroderma in  - after  years of suffering. The disease is caused by a person’s immune system attacking connective tissue under the skin, around organs and blood vessels. This hardens their insides, causing their tissue and organs - also including their bowels, oesophagus and kidneys - to solidy. “My disability is quite huge, Grace said. My heart, lungs, bowels, eyes, oesophagus, kidneys and hands are all badly affected because my scleroderma was not diagnosed at the early stages.  Scleroderma, affecting around , people in the UK, is treatable but not curable, with some of the most serious cases resulting in death. Grace’s late diagnosis means she cannot fully respond to any medications, stem cell treatments or organ transplants. This has left her with a “hopeless prognosis”. And my condition is so severe now because of late diagnosis. In my case everything is too late to help me, she said. The married mum-of-two is now backing a campaign by charity scleroderma and Raynauds UKcalling for faster diagnosis. Speaking about her initial diagnosis after a decade-long wait, she added: I I think my initial attitude towards my diagnosis was that of relief to think thank after about ten years or so of being told I should live with the pain, the actual cause of my symptoms was diagnosed.    “But then, with the hopeless prognosis for me, it quickly turned to that of despair.”  Other problems triggered by the condition include type  diabetes, lung disease and osteoarthritis.   On bad days, Grace struggles to get out of bed and avoids going out to socialise for fear of picking up infections.  Her lung damage is also so severe she uses a stair lt to move around her home.   Speaking about her early symptoms, Grace said she first noticed something wasn’t right when she began suffering from Raynaud’s after giving birth to her youngest child at the age of .  Raynauds affects the blood supply to certain parts of the body - usually fingers and toes - and is worsened by cold weather.   With her undiagnosed scleroderma slowly attacking her organs, she says doctors initially missed the rare condition.  Instead, they advised her to manage on pain killers - or even told her to migrate to a tropical country to help with her cold hands.  Over the next few years, Grace went on to notice her skin was hardening and tightening quickly and she stopped using nail polish and hair chemicals in a desperate bid to find a reason.  Despite this, she went on to live the next decade of her le undiagnosed and in pain, before one day being rushed to The Royal Brompton hospital in Cha suffering from extreme breathlessness.   An X-Ray on Grace’s chest revealed irreversibly damaged tissue along with serious damage to nearly all of her other organs. Medics diagnosed her with scleroderma before placing her on a course of chemotherapy.   While glad to finally get an explanation to her decade-long pain, Grace felt hopeless after discovering the diagnosis came too late.   She added: “My condition is so far advanced that some revolutionary medical discoveries such as stem cell or lung transplant cant help me.  Due to the severity of my lung disease, I experience constant breathlessness and extreme fatigue and my physical disability limits my ability to socialise, partially because I am highly susceptible to infections.  “This resulted in my early retirement at , so obviously that had affected our family income.   My children had to grow up quickly because of it.   “My husband is the one that had been most adversely affected from the onset of the illness - with having to deal with house chores, taking care of our children and keeping a full time job.”  Grace manages the aggressive nature of scleroderma with eight dferent medications as well as oxygen therapy.   She is now urging anyone who may show signs of scleroderma to contact a GP as soon as possible and has backed a campaign by SRUK for better diagnosis.  Grace added: “My condition is so severe due to late diagnosis that medications cannot help me - I find this extremely frustrating.   “I think many of the complications caused by my condition could have been preventedit had been diagnosed earlier, so it’s fantastic that SRUK are running a petition for better testing and faster diagnosis.”  Scleroderma affects an estimated , people in the UK and . million people across the world, with women four times more likely to be diagnosed. Around % of people have to make  or more visits to their GP before getting a diagnosis, with % of sufferers waiting more than  years for a diagnosis, research shows. Speaking about a campaign launched to raise awareness of the condition, Sue Farrington, Chief Executive of Scleroderma  Raynaud’s UK said: “We have launched this campaign to draw attention to the need for greater understanding of scleroderma and the importance of faster diagnosis for those with the condition.

title: parents shock after universal credit
story: NewsParents shock after Universal Credit leaves them with just p to live onThe panic-stricken parents Melissa Whitchurch and Chris Steer say they were told it was "their problem" by the Department for Work and PensionsShareCommentsByLaura Sharman:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsFriends and family have been donating food and supplies to help the couple "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family-of-three were expected to survive with less than a pound in their bank account for a week after a mistake over their benefits. In a panic, Melissa Whitchurch, , called the Department for Work and Pensions hotline but claim she was that it was her problem. Melissa and her partner Chris Steer were expecting a Universal Credit payment of pound to be paid into their bank account at midnight last Thursday and had budgeted accordingly. However, to the mum-of-ones horror, when she went to draw out the money, her balance was just  pence. Melissa claimed the officer said the payment was not due for another six days and, when she tried to explain the mistake, told her it was her problem and hung up.  The couple resorted to scouring their home to find things they could potentially sell so they could afford to feed their three-year-old daughter, Cheyanne. Melissa, from Brighton, East Sussex, said: All that was going through my mind was how am I going to feed my daughter and send her to school without her snacks  The children all put healthy food in a box at school in the morning, such as fruit and crackers, and then they sit down and eat it together during story time. It breaks my heart to think of her feeling like the odd one out, sat there watching everybody  eat their fruit when she doesnt have any. Melissa had originally asked the DWP to change her payment schedule from a monthly arrangement to a fortnightly one.  When the family received their last payment of pound, they were told the other half would arrive two weeks later and used the money to pay bills and buy food to last a fortnight. But when the second half did not arrive, Melissa was told it would be made on the last day of the month and was forced to wait six days with only  pence to her name. She said: Me and my partner can go without, but not our little girl. If we were told this in the first place, we would have budgeted for it. Its horrible. Cheyenne is really sweet about it and she doesnt really understand, thank goodness. We try to keep her away from it. But when she sees Im upset, she will come over and cuddle me and say its okay mummy. Its horrible and the people that are supposed to help just dont care. They are heartless.  The family have been surviving on food donations from strangers and neighbours who heard about their desperate situation. Have you been affected by Universal Credit  Email webnews@mirror  Melissa said: I could have gone to the food bank last week but since I thought I would be paid the next day, I didnt and the next one isnt for another week. So weve been getting by thanks to the kindness of other people. One lady heard about my situation and came and gave us some bread, milk, ham and cheese and Id never even seen or spoken to her before.  Melissa said she would love nothing more than toto work since she was signed off due to problems with her health  years ago. But the former shop assistant has limited mobility and has aids to help her around the house due to her back pain and other health issues, for which she takes more than  tablets per day.  Chris was also signed off from his job as a chef just five months ago for mental health reasons. Universal Credit is a new benefits system, introduced to simply and replace many existing benefits and tax credits and consists of a single, monthly benefit payment into a bank account. A DWP spokesperson said: “The vast majority of claimants are paid in full and on time, and are comfortable managing their money.Advance payments and budgeting support is available for anyone who needs extra help. “Universal Creditreplaces an out-of-date, complex benefits system with clf edges that disincentivised work and often trapped people in unemployment.Under UC, evidence shows people are moving into work faster and staying in work longer.The Mirror is urging our readers to back our petition to stop the rollout Universal Credit which is plunging families into debt and despair and replace it with a fair system.

Saturday and Sunday are also set to be wet and windy as the remains of Hurricane Oscar blows across the UK. WeatherOnline forecaster Garry Nicholson said: “The start of November is expected to become very unsettled as a strengthening jet stream brings powerful weather systems in from the south-west. “The remnants of Hurricane Oscar currently over the mid-Atlantic are likely to move close to the British Isles by the weekend with a threat of stormy winds and heavy rain.”  Three-day UK weather forecast Today : It is going to be a mostly cloudy day for many but with rain or showers for central and eastern areas. These will be mostly light in nature. Western Scotland, Northern Ireland, Wales and south-west England should remain dry with sunny spells. There will be brisk northerly winds in the east. Tonight : It will be a mostly dry evening with just a few showers lingering along the east coast. There will be a few clear spells especially after midnight. During the early hours a band of showers will affect western parts of Scotland and Wales, and north-west England, these will be light in nature. UK Outlook : Tomorrow it is going to be cloudy in the west with showers, these will be mostly light in nature. A drier and brighter day in the east with sunny spells. A wet start for many on Thursday with heavy rain across much of the south-east. It will be fair after noon with the odd light shower in the west.

story: NewsSix-year-old girl screams "Im dying daddy" after shes hit by shrapnel in the forgotten warEXCLUSIVE: We reveal the heartbreaking stories of the child victims of Yemens ongoing conflict, why it started, and the devastation that continues todayShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsIman cried as she lay on the ground in a pool of blood "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email“I’m dying daddy, I’m dying, I’m dying.” These are the harrowing screams of a six-year-old girl hit by shrapnel as she played in her back garden. Little Imans dad came home to find his young daughter lying helpless in a pool of blood on the ground. Iman, one of seven siblings, lives in the Altuhaitah district in Yemens Western Hodeidah with her family. She was in her back yard when an air strike hit her neighbours house in June, firing shrapnel towards her. Iman suffered severe injuries to her neck, hand and leg, while her three-month-old baby brother was also hurt. Her dad Salem was ing home from work as a labourer - where he earns the equivalent of just p-pound. a day - when he saw smoke billowing from their house.  Running to seehis family were still alive, he found his distressed daughter crying and screaming that she was dying. Fortunately, the youngster survived the horric ordeal. Save the Children have covered the costs of her treatment and she is due to get psychological support to help her cope with her experience. But she is just one child devastated in Yemen, amid a deadly conflict often dubbed the forgotten war. Aseel is two years old and suffers with cholera. The infectious disease causes severe diarrhea which can lead to dehydration and even deathuntreated. His young mum Salwa, who is four and a half months pregnant, also suffers with the disease. When Salwa, , first got sick, the family couldnt afford the bus fare to the hospital and her son also got infected.  Both family members have now managed to get treatment, but the mum worries about how shes going to make it to hospital to give birth safely. Ahmad, , meanwhile, was working in a fish market to help support his family when air strikes in the area left him badly injured in his leg and arm. The teenager, from Hodeidah, survived a first missile and was helping an injured man to an ambulance when a second missile struck him. He lost a lot of blood and fell into a coma, according to Save the Children. “The blood was everywhere it was a horrible scene I will never forget, he told the charity. I did not expect that the fish market would be targeted by the airstrikes. I always feel safe there but the airstrikes surprised me. When I was lying in the hospital I was thinking of my family and death. I was told that my friend who was selling water in the market was killed. A piece of shrapnel cut his head open while he was trying to escape.  My friend Hisham was only selling water in the market to help his family, just like me.” Ahmad is now recovering, but has still not been able to walk. The war in Yemen has been ongoing for three years - and has left the country in the worlds biggest humanitarian crisis. Children are the most badly affected. They face the threat of being hit by bombs, starvation and disease. Who is fighting who in the Yemen war  On one side of the war is the Houthi armed group - a rebel group linked to an Islamic sect - which was supported by some army units and armed groups loyal to late former president Ali Abdullah Saleh. On the other side is the military coalition led by Saudi Arabia and supported by President Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi, which has carried out air strikes in Yemen. Members of the coalition include the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Kuwait, Jordan and Sudan, according to Amnesty International. The organisation says that the USA and UK have also been providing key intelligence and logistical support to the coalition.  Why and how the war began- a timeline In , the Arab spring protests undermined then president Ali Abdullah Salehs rule. The uproar led to splits in the army and allowed al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsulato seize swathes of territory in the east. In , Saleh stepped down in a political transition plan backed by Gulf states. Abd-Rabbu Mansour Hadi became interim president and oversaw a “national dialogue” to draft a more inclusive, federal constitution. In , AQAP survived military onslaught and drone strikes, staging attacks across the country while retaining a persistent presence. The following year saw the Houthis seize Sanaa, the capital of Yemen, with the help of Saleh.  In , Hadi tried to announce a new federal constitution opposed by the Houthis and Saleh, who arrested him. He escaped, pursued by the Houthis, triggering Saudi intervention in March along with a hastily assembled Arab military coalition. Months later, the coalition drove the Houthis and Saleh loyalists from Aden in south Yemen and Marib, northeast of Sanaa, but the front lines solidied, setting up years of stalemate. In , hunger grew as the coalition imposed a partial blockade on Yemen, accusing Iran of smuggling missiles to the Houthis through Hodeidah alongside food imports - something it has denied. Coalition air strikes that killed civilians prompted warnings from rights groups, but Western support for the military campaign continued. In , the Houthis launched missiles into Saudi Arabia. Seeing a chance to regain power for his family by withdrawing from his Houthi allies, Saleh switched sides, but was killed trying to escape them.  What has happened this year In , coalition-backed forces have advanced up the Red Sea coast against the Houthis, aiming to take the port of Hodeidah. This is the last main entry point for supplies into north Yemen. Hodeidah is a leline for goods and aid for  percent of Yemen’s population, and disruption to this port could put the lives of hundreds of thousands of children in immediate danger while pushing millions more into famine. The United Nations has warned that failure to keep food, fuel and aid flowing into Yemen, particularly through Hodeidah, could result in one of the worst hunger crises in living history. How many people have been affected  According to Amnesty International, more than , civilians have been killed and injured. But other reports suggest up to , Yemenis have been killed because of the war. Amnesty reports around three million people have been forced away from their homes because of the fighting. The organisation says . million people are in need of le-saving assistance including water, food and shelter. And a staggering .million children are out of school.  What do children hurt in the war say  Noran, whose name has been changed, is wheelchair bound after a wave from an airstrike damaged her spine. The -year-old says: “I used to go to school on foot, my le was beautul because I could walk and write. Now, I can’t walk to school. I can only go with the wheelchair. I used to be able to sit in a chair at my desk and write but now when I try to write, my hand hurts because of the injury in my back. I used to love writing, but now I can’t even hold a pen.” The latest - a surge in suspected cholera cases Suspected cholera cases have almost tripled in Yemen’s coastal Hodeidah region since fighting escalated in June. The World Health Organisation says that  per cent of all suspected cases are children under five years old. The rise in suspected cases in Hodeidah follows a dramatic increase in fighting between the Houthis and forces backed by the Saudi- and Emirati-led Coalition since June. Between  and  July, airstrikes resulted in the damage of a sanitation facility and water station that supplies Hodeidah with most of its water. Hodeidah is also home to nearly , severely malnourished children – more than a quarter of Yemen’s total. More than half a million people have been displaced from their homes in Hodeidah since June. They have been forced to live in host communities in cramped conditions, with little access to clean water and sanitation.  Shocking figures - One civilian killed every three hours in Yemen One civilian has been killed every three hours in fighting in Yemen since the beginning of August, with many more people succumbing to disease and hunger, Oxfam said last week. Muhsin Siddiquey, Oxfam’s Country Director in Yemen said: “Every single le lost to this shameful conflict, be it through armed attacks, or through starvation and disease, should be an international outrage. “Backers of all the warring parties should realise that they are complicit in this man-made crisis. Governments must comply with all international legal obligations to do their utmost to prevent civilian casualties or damage to civilian infrastructure. The international community urgently needs to do everything it can to get all sides in this war to agree a ceasefire.” On Wednesday an airstrike in Hudaydah killed at least  civilians in a vegetable market. Earlier this month  civilians including four children were killed and  others were injured when an airstrike by the Saudi-led coalition hit two buses filled with passengers at a Houthi-held checkpoint to the south east of the city. A ground shelling at a camp for displaced people in southern Hudaydah killed a young woman and injured seven other people including six children. Sadly, the conflict continues.

title: man decapitated friends eight month
story: NewsMan faces firing squad for decapitating friends baby after heavy drinking sessionThe childs father discovered his daughters beaten body after ing home and finding her lying in the pool of blood with her head severedShareByWill Stewart:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsLeonid Klob, , discovered his daughter Annas bloodied body after ing home with his two sons "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man alleged to have decapitated an eight-month-old baby could face the death penalty. The child’s mother, Natalia Klob, , was also detained over the incident but women cannot be executed in the ex-Soviet state of Belarus. A paramedic fainted when she saw the bloody scene at a house in Luminets, according to law enforcement sources. Klob had been with a family friend only identied as Viktor, , when the child, Anna, was killed with a kitchen kne. Her husband Leonid, , discovered his daughters body after ing home with the couples two sons and finding her “lying in the pool of blood, her head severed”. Law enforcement official Dmitry Ivanyuk said: “On suspicion of committing the crime, the mother of the child and her friend were detained.”  A neighbour said: “When Leonid came into the flat he saw a scene out of the horror movies. “The ambulance doctor fainted when she came in.” Reports say the baby had been badly beaten before she was killed. The mother and her friend had been drinking, according to reports. Neighbours believed the family were happy and they had recently baptised the child in the Orthodox Church.  Belarus - an ex-Soviet state - is the sole country in Europe to retain the death penalty. Only men aged between  and  are executed. Those facing the death penalty are blindfolded and forced to kneel before being shot in the back of the head. The man and the child’s mother face a criminal case for murder of a child with particular cruelty. Under Belarus law, the maximum penalty for men for this crime is execution while for women it is up to  years in jail.

title: muslim woman 21 lashed public
story: NewsMuslim woman, , lashed in public under Sharia law for getting too close to her boyfriendThe -year-old was sentenced to a brutal lashing in front of crowds of bystandersShareCommentsByMirror:,  OCT NewsA young woman bows her head and kneels as she awaits being caned for getting too close to her boyfriend "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young woman and her boyfriend were whipped in public in Indonesia after being caught in close proximity to each other under draconian Sharia law. The -year-old was forced to kneel on a makesht stage with her head bowed before being caned with bamboo by a masked enforcer. She was then hauled off the  by two female police officers while her partner was also whipped as punishment for standing too close to each other in public. The public punishment took place in the city of Banda Aceh - where Sharia law is strictly practised and enforced.  The crime of being in close proximity to someone of the opposite sex can be punished by up to  lashes. Other offences such as gay sex, adultery, drinking alcohol and gambling can result in up to  lashes. Aceh is the only province in the country to impose Islamic criminal law and was granted increasingly special powers in  when the government struck a deal with separatists.  Indonesia is one of the most largely populated Muslm countries in the world with more than  per cent of the  million inhabitants practising the faith. Earlier this year a bride-to-be and her fiance were also publicly thrashed in the same city, after being found guilty of getting too close. Closeness is seen as a step towards pre-martial sex which is against Sharia Law and as a result the couple each received  lashes, in front of gathering crowds.  The punishments take place outside a mosque and draw huge crowds, many of whom take pictures. Meanwhile, in Malaysia, two women aged  and  were caned for having lesbian sex in a car. The women were sentenced to six lashings each and a fine of pound despite a global outcry from activists who say the sentence has no place in any civilised society.

title: about 500 dundee council workers overwhelmingly reject pay offer
story: About  city council workers have voted overwhelmingly to reject a pay offer from Cosla.Craft workers who are members of the union Unite – including joiners, painters, electricians and labourers – are the latest to reject the % pay increase.A spokesman for Unite said: “Unite the union confirm that its local government craft membership have voted to reject the Cosla pay offer by % and of those, % voted for industrial action.”Stuart Fairweather, chairman of Dundee Trades Union Council, said: “Unite is now hoping the strength of feeling will force Cosla to rethink the offer it is making.”

title: callum booth keen to keep feelgood factor going at dundee united
story: Callum Booth is delighted to see everyone associated with Dundee United pulling in the same direction and he’s determined to reward today’s travelling support with more to cheer at Dunfermline.The Tangerines head to East End Park today for new manager Robbie Neilson’s third match in charge.Despite only being in charge for a couple of weeks now, United left-back Booth says the new gaffer has already made quite an impression.He said: “It’s been brilliant, really good. Training has been really good and I thinkyou asked any of the boys in the changing-room we’d all be the same.“It’s really gone up a level, we’re all enjoying it and I think that shows on a Saturday.“It’s been quite tough but I think we needed that. It’s been enjoyable at the same time, though, and we’re all buying into his ideas.”Off the field there seems to be an air of optimism around Tannadice but Booth knows getting results on the pitch is the only way to realise their hopes of promotion.And that means keeping their unbeaten run under the new boss going against a Dunfermline side that have already bagged a deserved win over the Tangerines.Booth added: “Four points from the first two games isn’t too bad but I think they were two good performances as well.“We feel hard done by we didn’t get the win over Inverness – I think most people there would agree with that but it wasn’t to be.“At least we put in a really positive performance and everyone is pulling in the same direction.“There is a good feel about the place and, hopefully, we can kick on now and go on a little run.“The players, coaching staff, fans all seem to be pulling in the same direction especially since the new gaffer has come in.“A thousand fans down at Partick, great backing and then same again last weekend. The fans were right with us until the last minute.“It does help, it makes a massive dference and Dunfermline isn’t too far down the road so I’d expect another good away following.“I think the fans can see the work and effort we’re putting in, evenwe didn’t get the three points last Saturday.“The fans have been great and long may it continue.”Allan Johnston’s Pars have been struggling of late after a lightning fast start to the season saw them follow up four wins from four in the Betfred Cup group stage with an impressive - victory at Tannadice.Since then, Dunfermline have only managed eight points from the following eight games and were beaten - at home last weekend despite dominating against Queen of the South.In fact, scoring goals at home has been a real problem of late with just the two Championship strikes going in.Booth  Co., however, are wary of a repeat show from the Pars.He said: “Dunfermline were really good at Tannadice the first time we played them and thoroughly deserved to win.“I think most people would be surprised they’ve not kicked on from that first game.“They played well that day and deserved the win.“I’ve not seen much of them since but it’s not worked out for them since for whatever reason.“They’ll still be a dangerous opponent, though, because they are, obviously, capable of putting in a performance but have just been a bit inconsistent recently.“If we go about it like we have done in the last two games then we’ll give ourselves a chance.“We’ll be going there in positive spirits, try to take our chances and come back up the road with the three points.”

title: disruption with major dundee road closed for resurfacing
story: A number of bus services are delayed this morning due to the closure of a major Dundee road.Dura Street in Stobswell, between Brown Constable Street and Erskine Street – a busy route for people travelling to and from the city centre – has been closed to allow carriageway resurfacing work to be carried out.Motorists are currently experiencing disruption and both major bus companies covering the city have reported delays.A statement from Xplore Dundee said: #Traffic delays continue to affect services   |  |   due to Dura St closure.#It added: #Services also encounter temp. traffic lights at Meadowside  services   still have additional lights on Pitkerro Rd.#Our driving team is working hard to maintain service nevertheless.mdash Xplore DundeeOctober , Stagecoach East Scotland said that the road closure was causing delays on services  , A, A  and .Tayside Contracts, which is doing the work on behalf of Dundee City Council, plans to have it completed by Friday.Roads maintenance staff were on site yesterday to prepare for the start of the work.It’s the latest in a series of closures affecting Stobswell – with traders complaining in the past about lost business due to a lack of passing trade.However, Colin Clement, of the Stobswell Forum, said he was hopeful this latest work would have minimal impact on locals.A spokesman for Dundee City Council said: “These roadworks are part of an ongoing roads maintenance programme across the city.“Diversions will be in operation during the works and these will be signposted for motorists.”Meanwhile, a series of other roadworks affecting Stobswell and the surrounding area will get under way next week.Starting next Monday, temporary traffic lights will be put up at ious locations to allow for BT Openreach cabling works on Victoria Street, Crescent Street, Dens Road, Lyon Street, Dura Street and Ogilvie Street for two weeks.A BT Openreach spokeswoman said: “We’ve been asked to reroute existing cables which provide high speed internet links used by local businesses.“Temporary traffic management will be in place with someone on site to manage any traffic issues that arise and measures will be put in place to minimise any impact to pedestrians.”

title: dundee appoint jimmy boyle as new assistant manager
story: Dundee have appointed Jimmy Boyle as assistant manager to Jim McIntyre.The -year-old steps up from his post as head of the Dark Blues youth academy to team up with the new boss who arrived to succeed Neil McCann last week.Jimmy has been in the dugout for the games against Livingston and Hearts and confirmation he’s to remain their permanently brings to an end the Billy Dodds saga that’s dragged on since the new manager arrived last week.Dodds, who was Jim’s number two at Ross County, was his first choice for the same post at Dens Park, but well documented matters relating to his departure after Dundee went into administration in  made him unacceptable to many Dark Blues fans.As well as him, it’s understood Dens legend Barry Smith and Aberdeen coach Barry Robson were also being considered.But Jim has opted for another man he knows well and who has extensive experience in coaching and management.The pair played together at Airdrie and during eight years with the Diamonds, Jimmy appeared in two Scottish Cup finals.After a career that included spells at a string of clubs including Queen’s Park, Livingston and Partick Thistle, he was Airdrie’s under- coach for several seasons before succeeding Kenny Black as manager in .He was sacked three years later, but was quickly appointed to the SFA’s coaching staff and in  was headhunted by Dundee to take charge of developing their emerging talent.Over the last two-and-half-years he’s transformed the fortunes of the club’s underage sides and last season saw him steer the Development squad to a second place finish in their league.Known for someone who prefers to stay out of the limelight, he has been persuaded to make the step back up to first team level and assist his old team-mate in keeping Dundee in the Premiership.A Dundee FC statement said: #Jimmy has been with the club since joining as head of youth development in . During that period he has overseen the academy while also managing the development side and helping out with the first team.

title: dundee tourist guide fiona becomes official ambassador for city
story: A Dundee tourist guide has become an official ambassador for the city, giving her the chance to showcase not only the city, but all of Scotland, to visitors from all over the world.Fiona Mackenzie was presented with her Blue Badge Guide certicate by the Duke of Argyll.Ms Mackenzie, who lives in Lf, is one of just two guides in the city who hold the badge, which allows them to take visitors from all over the world on tours anywhere in Scotland.She was presented with her certicate at a ceremony in Linlithgow after completing an -month course organised by the Scottish Tourist Guides Association .Fiona said: “The combination of academic work, research and practical skills is very demanding. However, having worked last year as a student and now completed my first season as a qualied guide, I find it all fits together.“Meeting new people and sharing Scotland with them is just great.”Before achieving her blue badge, Fiona had a ied career, living in Brussels, Budapest, London and Edinburgh.She added: “I’ve always been interested in everything about Scotland and the course helped me understand the background to it all, the reasons why things look like they do or happened like they did, so I will use that to entertain my clients as well as inform them.”Blue badge students cover a wide range of subjects including history, art, archaeology, geology, industry, film, wildle, TV and sports.

title: dundee united women on the road to the top after league win
story: Dundee United Women are already looking ahead to next season after clinching the Scottish Women’s Football League One title at Tannadice Park after an emphatic victory over Cove Rangers.It was the first time the United girls had played an official match on Tannadice itself and it turned out to be extra special with silverware presented at the end of a - win.Captain Keira Johnstone said: “I am massively proud of the girls and what we have achieved.“It was a big day for us and the team performed brilliantly.“Everyone has worked hard, players and coaches, to gain promotion to the Scottish Women’s Premier League . We can’t wait to get started next season.”Head coach Gavin Beith added: “To finish the season off the way we did was very pleasing and doing this at Tannadice made it such a special day for everyone involved.“On and off the park so many people have worked extremely hard over the years to support the team and it’s a fitting way to cap off a good season.“Playing SWPL football is going to be exciting for us all.”Paul Wilson, the Community Coaching Manager, commented: “I’m delighted. The girls were excellent.#They handled the pressure of playing at Tannadice and rose to the challenge. They pulled together and the crowd of  really got behind them.”The United girls won , drew three and lost one of their  league games with a goal dference of plus .

title: kylie minogues random appearance at local nightclub being auctioned off
story: It’s dficult to imagine Kylie Minogue randomly turning up at a nightclub in Angus.But in the late s, Flicks in Brechin had a surprise visit from the pop princess, pictured, at a time when it was voted the number one nightspot in the UK and featured a spectacular light and laser show.Steve Wright was a regular DJ there and late EastEnders star Leslie Grantham and glamour model Samantha Fox were among the special guests.Now, the building that once hosted the cream of the country’s entertainment scene is going up for auction next month.Former owner Stuart Aikenhead isn’t all that sad to see it go – but the -year-old still retains fond memories of his time running the venue with fellow Brechin men Mike Swilinski and Pete Barr.Having previously run a mobile disco, the trio took an £, gamble and bought the old Kings Cinema and transformed it into a state-of-the-art nightclub.Stuart said: “If we had listened to the money people then we would never have opened, as we were constantly advised it was such a huge risk. But we were young and had that goal in mind.”Flicks opened on December  , the club’s name and recognisable cinema ticket logo a nod to the building’s previous le.Stuart said: “It was about creating something in Brechin that locals could enjoy.“What made Flicks so special was the support we had from the local community, other local businesses and the police.“DC Thomson played a huge part in our success. One of the reporters, James Masson, gave us major support, was always looking for a story and inwe got a lot of coverage. And that’s not forgetting that Brechin was seen as being in the middle of nowhere to the outside world.”With Dundee, Aberdeen and Perth all within an hour’s travelling time and the Edzell US Naval base on the doorstep, there was a huge customer base. People even came from as far away as Newcastle.Shrewd marketing – such as free ticket offers to people turning  or  – and buses taking revellers to the club and home again often led to a packed venue.Stuart said: “A lot of the success we had was partly down to having the right thing at the right time.“The nightclub and pop scene were at their peak in the mid-s. We also had a strong business relationship with PWL, Pete Waterman’s business.”Brechin hosted a number of the record boss’s chart-toppers of the day, including Jason Donovan, Bananarama and Rick Astley.Waterman’s television show The Hitman and Her was also filmed live in Flicks four times.“The time Kylie Minogue appeared was a complete surprise,” said Stuart.“I got a call to say ‘there’s someone wants to come and see Flicks’ – but they didn’t say who it was.“Kylie was in the local area doing something  and they brought her in as a surprise visitor.“It’s incredible to look back and think, ‘this all happened in Brechin’.”Stuart and Mike sold the business in . It changed hands again a few times before closing permanently in .Stuart, who is now retired and splits his time between Florida and Brechin with we Carol, said: “It’s very sad to see the state of the building.“I can’t see it ever being used as either a cinema or nightclub again. I would tear the whole thing down, and open it up to use as off-street parking.“The back of the building is full of asbestos and would need a lot of work on it to make it safe. That would cost a lot of money.”

title: man with candlestick holder shouted and swore at concierge at dundee multi
story: A man shouted and swore at concierge staff while holding a large wooden candlestick holder at a Dundee multi.Before his outburst, Szymon Pawlowski, , of Dallfield Court, repeatedly phoned the concierge office at Bonnethill Court.Fiscal depute Kirsten Letford told Dundee Sherf Court that Pawlowski was phoning to complain about another male being a “nuisance”.She said: “He was told that police were dealing with it and there was nothing they could do.“He became irate and contacted them a further two times.”Pawlowski then went to the concierge office and was aggressive, shouting and swearing at a male member of staff.The fiscal said: “The concierge asked the accused to calm down, then he noticed the accused was holding a large wooden item in his hand. He did not brandish the item but, due to his aggression and the fact he had no other reason to be there, the concierge felt threatened.”Police came to Pawlowski’s flat and he identied a large wooden candlestick holder as the item he had been holding.Speaking for himself at court, Pawlowski said: “I was trying to get help as I saw police come in – I was trying to tell them about the drunk guy below my balcony that had been screaming for two hours.“I had been attacked by three guys who came to my side. They had two glasses of beer in their hands. I thought I was going to get it put on my head. All I was doing was self defence. I was scared.”Pawlowski admitted aggressive behaviour by shouting and swearing while in possession of the large wooden object on June . Sentence was deferred until April .

title: new midfielder could figure for dundee in celtic clash
story: Boss Jim McIntyre could have more selection options available when his team face champions Celtic at Dens Park on Wednesday.However, he’ll still have at least a couple of men out injured.Full-back Nathan Ralph and centre-half Genseric Kusunga were not ready to face Hearts on Tuesday evening.Both, though, have been back in training this week and that could put them in contention for a place against the Hoops next midweek.Midfielder Martin Woods, who’s been training at Dens this week, could also be handed a contract in time for involvement in the next outing.However, the likes of Paul McGowan and Josh Meekings are expected to remain on the sidelines as they continue their battles to get back fit after y absences.The club are expected to announce McIntyre’s assistant later today.

title: tom duthie neil mccann tried to change too much too soon at dundee
story: When Neil McCann looks back on his time as Dundee boss he will surely learn several lessons, ones that can stand him in good steadhe s to management.Perhaps the most obvious will be that, whatever your football philosophy, it has to be tapered to suit the resources you have available when it comes to players.McCann’s mantra at Dens was to play passing football at all times and, ultimately, at all costs. That led to too many goals being lost by errors as, at high risk, the ball was played out from the back.It became increasingly clear some of his defenders in particular were not comfortable with this policy but the manager was not for budging and persevered with the style of play he was convinced would, ultimately, bring success.The number of goals it cost made it inevitable what many saw as stubbornness was what cost McCann his job.That is, perhaps, an over-simplication and, now the dust has settled on the former Scotland international’s departure, a more in-depth look throws up other factors.A look at the players he used in his eight Premiership games in charge this term highlights another couple of causes for his downfall.First off, the list of those involved looks too long. In just two-and-a-half months of league football, Dundee fielded  dferent players.Of course, injury and suspension means some of the constant stream of changes were enforced, but others suggest he was never totally sure of what his best line-up was. Given the style of play he wanted, this lack of consistency in selection had to be an issue.Arguably, an even bigger one was that he fell into the rookie manager’s trap of trying to make too many changes too quickly.The Premiership may not be one of the top leagues in Europe but it does have its own unique qualities. One of them, as most new arrivals testy, is the tempo of the play here is more frantic than in many other countries.Even players coming up from England, where the pace is higher than on the continent, usually comment on that.What that means is players from where have to be given time to adjust and, as they do, it’s important they have men around them who are already experienced campaigners in our top ision.A glance down the list of the men used this season suggests there were not enough performers who fitted into that category.Of the  he used, nine were completely new to the league, while eight others had no more than a season’s experience of it.Ironically, the most used who fell into those categories was when  started the solitary win at Hamilton last month but, in the other outings, seven or eight such players were used.That’s not saying these players are not good enough for this level but, as most experienced managers in any league will say, whatever the level of talent, having so many who are not familiar with their surroundings is a risk they wouldn’t be prepared to take.While McCann did bring in vastly-experienced Premiership performer Kenny Miller at the end of the summer transfer window, the loss through injury of Paul McGowan had to be a major blow.And it should not be seen as insignicant that, as he’s scoured the free-agent market since his arrival as manager, new boss Jim McIntyre has paid particular attention to men who know the top flight well.Martin Woods is expected to sign up once he’s proved his fitness, though Celtic on Wednesday may be too early for that. Woods’ old Ross County team-mate from when McIntyre was in charge, Paul Quinn, has also been linked.
